title.narrative: International Centre for Integrated Mountain Dev. (ICIMOD), 2011-2016
International Centre for Integrated Mountain Dev. (ICIMOD), 2011-2016

description.narrative: Sida stödjer organisationen International Centre for Intergrated Mountain Development´s två regionala program: 1) Reducing the impacts of Black Carbon and other short- lived climate forcers. 2) The Himalayan Climate Change Adaptation programme. Sverige bidrar med 50 MSEK. Fokuset är att minska utsläpp av korta klimatgaser samt att uppnå bättre kunskap om effekter av klimatförändringar/ anpassning.

Sida supports two of ICIMODs regional programmes. 1) The Black Carbon Programmes aims att enhancing scientific understanding of black carbon and other short- lived climate forcers. 2) The Himalayan Climate Change Adaptation programme aims at reducing the uncertanties of impact of climate change the development , enhance capcity etc. The support is estimated to 50 MSEK.

participating-org.narrative: ICIMOD/International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: HICAP: Overall, HICAP has attained a high degree of achievement of the original objectives set out during the project design. The first objective, Reduce uncertainty through downscaling and customizing global climate change scenarios and develop water availability and demand scenarios for parts of major river basins, has been achieved to large extent, with the downscaling work being completed and published in several international peer-reviewed journals and in a more accessible form in the Himalayan Climate and Water Atlas providing climate and hydrological scenario for up to 2050. Using the results of the HICAP work, other initiatives and partners of ICIMOD are taking the research forward with further development of the modelling approach and considering the Paris Agreement targeting a 1.5 degree world. The second objective, Develop knowledge and enhance capacities to assess, monitor and communicate the impacts of and responses to climate change (compounded with other drivers of change) on natural and socio-economic environments at local, national and regional level, has also been achieved to a large extent. HICAP has produced 86 knowledge products on the impacts and responses to climate and other changes in the region, which have been downloaded 42 361 times and cited 475 times. The media engagement has resulted in almost 400 stories. For the third objective, Make concrete and actionable proposals for strategies and policies considering vulnerabilities, opportunities and potentials for adaptation, particular reference to strengthening the role of women and local communities, there have been significant strides. As reported in previous paragraphs, HICAP has been able to provide concrete, solution oriented recommendations to stakeholders, many of which have been taken up. These efforts will continue in 2017 and 2018 under the support from Norway, and have influenced the development of ICIMOD’s next Medium-Term Action Plan to focus on solution-oriented ‘packages’ of practices. The overall planned goal of HICAP, of “Contributing to enhanced resilience to change, particularly climate change, through improved understanding of vulnerabilities, opportunities and potentials for adaptation, and the development of strategies and policies based on scientific/evidence-based knowledge in the HKH,” is a long-term goal which is difficult to track and possibly cannot be expected to fully come to fruition within the programme’s 5-6 year time span. However, many of the programme’s achievements have set a course toward contributing to this impact in the longer term, by building the capacities of and providing adaptive and resilient solutions to key stakeholders, particularly the regional government.
Atmosphere: The initiative’s work has contributed to the availability of new scientific datasets on emissions from a number of different pollutant sources as well as ambient air quality in a number of places. It has trained scientists and government technicians, as well as journalists, and contributed to a more aware public. In several sectors, notably brick production, it has contributed directly to economically viable reduction of emissions. It has brought together scientists from across the region to work collaboratively and it has contributed to policymaking at multiple levels, including working closely with the Climate and Clean Air Coalition at a global level.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
